Hello Oliver,

I've taken this approach, though I used another TWEANN syste=
m, not NEAT, to drive the neural substrate. In my case the results were not=
 better than using a standard TWEANN, I've played around with both 2 layers=
 and 3. The resolution required is substantial, and so using hypercube enco=
ding rather than the standard is computationally more expensive in this sce=
nario.

Regards,
-Gene

--- On Sat, 2/12/11, Oliver Coleman <oliver@e-geek.=
com.au> wrote:

From: Oliver Coleman <oliver@...>
Subject: [neat]=
 Re: Time Series with HyperNEAT
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Saturday, Fe=
bruary 12, 2011, 11:06 PM







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      

=
  
  
    A 1D temporal signal can be converted to a 2D geometric signal by=

    plotting the signal over some time window. (I think) Theoretically,
  =
  assuming the signal is predictable, the window is large enough and
    th=
e network has enough representational power then a feed-forward
    network=
 can be trained to make predictions on the signal. It would
    be interest=
ing to see how HyperNEAT performs on such a problem
    domain; I'm not awa=
re of any research on this (using HyperNEAT),
    does anyone know of any?
=

    

    Cheers,

    Oliver

    
      
        E: oliver@...=


        P: 0421
          972 953 (Aus.), +61 421 972 953
          (Intl=
.)

        Skype: oliver.coleman

        W: www.e-geek.com.au
        - c=
ommercial web services.

        W: www.enviro-geek.net
        - not-for-p=
rofit web services.
      
    
    

    On 08/12/10 05:50, petar_chervens=
ki wrote:
    
      =C2=A0
      
          
            Time series predi=
ction is a 1D problem and I am skeptical
              about the advantage =
of HyperNEAT over other methods like
              regular NEAT and other r=
ecurrent NN based approaches. It
              seems that a lot of people g=
ot to know about HyperNEAT's
              ability to overcome a lot of cha=
llenges and then try to
              apply it to everything, without knowi=
ng it's internal
              workings, mainly the CPPN theory and the way=
 CPPNs
              generate patterns. Trying HyperNEAT on everything is g=
ood,
              though, it sheds light on what tasks the algorithm works=

              and where it fails. It would be good to know if HyperNEAT
  =
            performs well in time series prediction. Perhaps some kind
    =
          of data preprocessing, which makes geometrical sense,
           =
   should help. I personally have tried time series
              predictio=
n with HyperNEAT and had no better results than
              regular NEAT,=
 even worse. 

              

              Peter

              

       =
       --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,
              "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrot=
e:

              >

              > 

              > 

              > Pe=
ter, you could use any version of HyperNEAT
              currently availab=
le for your task, but the main question
              is whether the geomet=
ry (or regularities) of the time
              series can somehow be made a=
n advantage to HyperNEAT
              through the configuration of the sub=
strate. It is not
              immediately clear why HyperNEAT in particul=
ar is
              advantageous for time series problems, though it is
   =
           possible it can be leveraged in some way that is helpful.
      =
        

              > 

              > As an alternative, you could al=
so try regular NEAT as
              well. Also, if you search through the =
archives of this
              group you will find a number of discussions =
on time series
              prediction.

              > 

              >=
 ken

              > 

              > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,
      =
        "Peter" <blackprinzze@> wrote:

              > >

              > =
> Hi

              > > 

              > > I'm currently trying to develop=
 HyperNEAT for
              Time series forecasting (Stock & commodity)

 =
             > > 

              > > 1, Is there a current version of Hyper=
NEAT
              available that my be suited for this task?

            =
  > > 

              > > 2, If not can you please point me in the right
  =
            direction, explaining how this can be achieved. 

             =
 > > 

              > > 3, Forecast should behave, similar to that of a
  =
            Moving average, with forecast plots one period or more
        =
      into the future. 

              > > 

              > > Thanks

    =
          > > 

              > > Peter

              > >

              >=


              

            
          
          
      
      
    
  
=

    network can =

    domain; I'm not aware of=

nal

        =

              p=
erforms well in time series prediction. Perhaps some kind

              should hel=

              prediction with HyperN=
EAT and had no better results than
